newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia torn by outback euthanasia death.
newsitem.headline: Australia torn by outback euthanasia death.

text.p: An Australian cancer patient who said he lived on a "roller-coaster of pain" has committed the world's first legally-assisted suicide, sparking a fiery national debate on the issue of mercy killing.
Bob Dent, a 66-year-old former carpenter from this northern outback city, died from a computer-delivered lethal injection last Sunday after persuading doctors he had nothing to live for.
He shared a last meal and drink with doctor Philip Nitschke and told him that what he was doing was an "act of love".
"If I were to keep a pet animal in the same condition I am in, I would be prosecuted," Dent wrote in an open letter to Australian members of parliament on the eve of his death.
"For months I have been on a roller-coaster of pain made worse by the unwanted side effects of the drugs."
Australian church leaders, who want the Northern Territory voluntary euthanasia law quashed, were outraged.
Sydney's Roman Catholic archbishop Edward Clancy said he was "deeply ashamed that Australia should be the only country in the world to legalise the killing of an innocent person.
"Respect, reverence for human life is a cornerstone of our civilisation," Clancy said. "When that goes, our society begins to unravel."
Dent's death marked the first time that the Northern Territory's euthanasia law had been successfully used since it came into operation on July 1.

It saw battlelines drawn up on Thursday for a fresh fight over mercy killing. Government backbencher Kevin Andrews, who has launched a private action in federal parliament to have the state's law quashed, said euthanasia was now a national issue.
It also polarised opinion in Australia, with one state politician describing it as "beautiful" and church leaders expressing their shame.
Victoria state premier Jeff Kennett, a supporter of voluntary euthanasia, said moves to have the law quashed were immoral.
"For people to be able to die with grace and dignity at their choosing as opposed to suffering is just beautiful," Kennett told reporters.
"Life is about choice; death should be about choice and politicians ought to butt out."
Nitschke told reporters up to five more people from around Australia had sought to use the legislation and that another death could occur within weeks.
"There is little doubt that the events surrounding this first use of the act will make it that much easier for the next terminally ill person," Nitschke said.
The doctor, dubbed Australia's "Doctor Death" after American euthanasia campaigner Jack Kevorkian, said the atmosphere in Dent's Darwin home had at first been tense.
But he said Dent had reassured him as he died, telling him that what he was doing was "an act of love".
"The patient was expressing a sense of gratitude. He was as happy as someone could be under the circumstances," he said.
Dent wrote that he he had been an active, outgoing person and that "being unable to live a normal life causes much mental and psychological pain, which can never be relieved by medication".
The deputy prime minister in Australia's conservative government, Tim Fischer, repeated warnings the territory law was a move towards "a culture of death".
Prime Minister John Howard, Labor opposition leader Kim Beazley, other prominent community leaders and Australia's indigenous Aborigines have all condemned the law.

Previous political and legal challenges against the law in the Northern Territory have failed, although a coalition of doctors, church and Aboriginal leaders have petitioned the Australian High Court to declare the law unconstitutional.
Dent in his letter urged parliament to allow people to choose to die when Andrews' bill is voted on later this year.

"The church and state should be kept separate," he wrote. "What right has anyone because of their own religious faith, to which I don't subscribe, to demand that I behave according to their rules and endure unnecessary intractable pain.
"If you disagree with voluntary euthanasia, then don't use it, but please don't deny the right to me to use it."
